q: 1. If he _____ earlier, he wouldn't have missed the train.
expl: A. left – Simple past; not correct for third conditional.
B. had left – past perfect is required in third conditional.
C. leaves – Present tense; incorrect in this context.
D. would have left – Wrong tense for this part of the conditional.

q: 2. I wish I _____ how to solve this problem.
expl: A. know – Present tense; 'wish' for present uses past tense.
B. knew – past tense expresses a present unreal situation.
C. have known – Present perfect; not used after 'wish'.
D. will know – Future; incorrect after 'wish'.

q: 3. Hardly _____ the bell rung when the students rushed out.
expl: A. has – Present perfect; wrong tense.
B. had – after 'hardly', use past perfect.
C. did – Simple past; not suitable here.
D. have – Plural present; not suitable here.

q: 4. The man _____ wallet was stolen reported the theft.
expl: A. who's – Contraction for 'who is'; incorrect.
B. whose – possessive relative pronoun.
C. whom – Object pronoun; not possessive.
D. who – Subject pronoun; not possessive.

q: 5. I prefer tea _____ coffee.
expl: A. than – Used for comparisons, not 'prefer'.
B. from – Incorrect preposition here.
C. to – 'prefer A to B' is standard.
D. over – Informal but less standard.

q: 6. Neither the teacher nor the students _____ ready.
expl: A. is – Incorrect; 'students' is plural and closest to verb.
B. are – verb agrees with the nearest subject.
C. was – Wrong tense and number.
D. be – Not a proper verb form here.

q: 7. He talks as if he _____ everything.
expl: A. knows – Present tense; doesn't express unreality.
B. know – Wrong verb form.
C. knew – 'as if' for unreal present uses past tense.
D. had known – Past perfect; incorrect here.

q: 8. She suggested that he _____ to the doctor.
expl: A. goes – Present simple; not subjunctive.
B. go – subjunctive after 'suggest'.
C. will go – Future; not used after 'suggest that'.
D. gone – Past participle; incorrect here.

q: 9. Not only _____ late, but he also forgot his book.
expl: A. he arrived – No inversion after 'not only' at the start.
B. did he arrive – inversion after 'not only' at the start.
C. arrived he – Wrong word order.
D. he did arrive – Incorrect structure.

q: 10. The book, together with the notes, _____ missing.
expl: A. are – Plural; but subject is singular.
B. were – Plural; same as above.
C. is – 'together with' doesn't change subject number.
D. have been – Present perfect plural; subject is singular.

q: 11. Scarcely _____ the train left when it began to rain.
expl: A. did – Simple past; incorrect after 'scarcely'.
B. has – Present perfect; wrong tense.
C. had – past perfect after 'scarcely'.
D. have – Not correct here.

q: 12. It's high time you _____ to bed.
expl: A. go – Present tense; not correct after 'it's high time'.
B. went – past tense shows urgency.
C. have gone – Present perfect; not used here.
D. gone – Not a valid verb form here.

q: 13. By the time she arrives, we _____ our work.
expl: A. finished – Simple past; does not fit future reference.
B. have finished – Present perfect; not for future reference.
C. will have finished – future perfect for something completed before another future event.
D. had finished – Past perfect; for past, not future.

q: 14. Each of the boys _____ given a present.
expl: A. have – Plural; incorrect after 'each'.
B. was – 'each' takes singular verb.
C. were – Plural; not correct.
D. are – Plural; not correct.

q: 15. Had I seen him, I _____ hello.
expl: A. would say – Wrong tense for past unreal.
B. would have said – past unreal condition.
C. had said – Incorrect; not the right conditional form.
D. will say – Simple future; not correct here.

q: 16. He denied _____ the window.
expl: A. breaking – 'deny' is followed by gerund.
B. to break – Infinitive; not used after 'deny'.
C. break – Bare infinitive; incorrect here.
D. to have broken – Perfect infinitive; not common after 'deny'.

q: 17. She is one of the students who _____ always late.
expl: A. is – Would refer to 'one', not 'students'.
B. was – Wrong tense and number.
C. are – 'who' refers to 'students' (plural).
D. has been – Singular present perfect; not correct.

q: 18. This is the best movie I _____.
expl: A. ever saw – Simple past; should use present perfect.
B. had ever seen – Past perfect; used with another past event.
C. have ever seen – present perfect with superlative.
D. ever see – Present simple; not correct here.

q: 19. I look forward to _____ from you soon.
expl: A. hear – Bare infinitive; not used after 'look forward to'.
B. hearing – 'to' is a preposition, followed by gerund.
C. heard – Past tense; not correct here.
D. to hear – Infinitive; not used here.

q: 20. No sooner had he left _____ it started to rain.
expl: A. than – 'No sooner... than' is the correct structure.
B. when – Often confused, but incorrect here.
C. then – Incorrect structure.
D. but – Incorrect connector.
